title: Monday, 22nd January, 2018
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas good morning everyone
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hi. Hello. Good morning. Welcome to Monday.

BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's you know, this thing.

Soundbuy Morning
Manxish Morning all
Badger Morning. I think I'm going to change my name to Bitcoin Badger so that I feel more valued.
BE11:04am

Joining me shortly, assuming the system works, will be Tom Hale ....

Swedish chef It’s time to play the music..
GBKrona Hola
11:04 am
BE11:04am

In the meantime, have a picture.

BE11:05am

Mr Hancock's a trained jockey, you know. It seems to be law that every story on the gambling triennial points this out.

Shinshin Is that the shrewdette pick for Cheltenham ?

Hello all

Groundhog Day Hey guys. Good morning. Hope you had a good weekend. Remember Neil said something on Aptiv/Continental - any thoughs on that in light of CFO comments "4-5bn deal capacity"? I know Neil isn't here - but still. Thanks!

Here's the horse whispering in the Sunday Times ....

BE11:07am

Matt wants the new stake to be at the bottom of the range. His attitude to FOBT is very negative because it takes money from reasonable, mature betting, like on the horses. He thinks these machines are a social blight.

Mouselet Glad to see the FOBT-regulating people do appear not to be completely supine, though it would be kind of good for that sort of information to come out by press release rather than by leak
BE11:07am

https://www.thetim...gambling-ftc6v37hr

Badger @TomD- deepest sympathy presumably

And it's fleshed out by all other papers this morning, including this one.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

https://www.ft.com...-9650-9c0ad2d7c5b5

BE11:07am

An official at the Department for Culture, Media and Sport said no formal decision has been made but the £2 limit was highly likely.

Mouselet Fundamentally they are a sort of tuppence machine and there is no reason for the stake not to be 2p
BE11:07am

Now ..............

Swedish chef Reasonable mature betting: it’s what we do...
Tom Dalgleish @Badger, for the bereaved yes
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Few things to note here aside from the prices .....

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 296.00, down 40.3 (-11.98%), High: 300.40, Low: 285.10, Volume: 8.63m
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 164.70, down 17.75 (-9.73%), High: 165.65, Low: 158.75, Volume: 22.94m

Firstly, it's worth highlighting here is that the consultation period doesn't even end until tomorrow.

BE11:09am

There's no official date for publication of the report, but second quarter was generally assumed.

Alchemy30 Morning,LCL CEO comment 'significant reduction in the level of funding for horse racing'
Swedish chef Bitcoin & FOBTs we leave to muppets
Alchemy30 maybe aimed at someone in particular
11:10 am
BE11:10am

So .......... does effectively pre-announcing the outcome via "friends of Matt" and unnamed officials before the closure of consultation period leave the government open to a judicial review?

BE11:10am

We also, I assume, have the to get the Treasury's view.

Forester @BE well it will certainly open the way for a few months of intense lobbying and "threats" i.e. store closures, reduced money for racing etc
BE11:11am

And I'm not totally sure that the Treasury will share Matt's opinion, given a different set of priorities.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The gist of the sellside this morning is all, "this report, if it's right -- and the Sunday Times is very anti FOBT so let's not get carried away, would mean ...."

BE11:13am

Which looks like clutching at straws. It's written by Tim Shipman, for starters, not the business desk, and has been matched by all other media this morning.

BE11:13am

Have some Davy.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

If the government was to move to a £2 limit, it is likely that there would be significant shop closures in the UK – a KPMG study for the Association of British Bookmakers put the figure at over 3,000 (out of a total in the UK of just less than 9,000). That would have knock-on implications for the funding of British racing. Further consolidation would almost certainly occur as William Hill would look to scale up its online operations and to diversify away from the UK. For GVC, the importance of its other online markets would increase. For those operators without substantial retail operations, their competitors would be weakened.

freddy what are your opinions on ripple?
BE11:13am

We estimate that such a move would reduce LCL standalone EBITDA by 28% and William Hill EBITDA by 24%. We estimate that the EBITDA impact on pro-forma GVC-LCL would be c.18%. Vis-à-vis a £20 outcome, the EPS impact on GVC-LCL would be 13% and for William Hill would be 34%. That said, under such a scenario, further sector consolidation would be inevitable.

BE11:14am

And Canaccord.

Tom Dalgleish So as William Hill is selling out of Aussie does it have counterintelligence?
11:15 am
BE11:15am

We would argue that declining OTC betting on horses is a factor of the rising popularity of football betting, and a structural shift towards online. We see very limited substitutional spend on racing in the event of eliminating B2 machines. Given the impact of significant shop closures - we see at least 2,000 shops closing, or 23% of the UK's retail betting shops - there would be a significant impact on funding for the racing industry.
Mr Hancock's conclusion also seems to go against the views of the Responsible Gambling Strategy Board, an independent body providing advice to the Gambling regulator. The RGSB could see no fundamental justification for a cut in max stakes much below £50. It points out that the average cash burn rate for a B3 machine (i.e. max stake x spins per hour x average return to player) is £302; at a £2 max stake, a B2 machine would have an average cash burn of just £10, given the same max stake as a B3 machine, but a much slower spin speed. As such, it suggests B2s would cease to exist at a £2 max stake. Finally, his conclusions are likely to be at odds with the Treasury, which will be concerned at the significant loss of tax revenues (over £500m of machines gaming taxes, employment/property taxes on the retail estate, corporation tax, etc.).

Waterloo If 3000 close will leave big holes on the high st with little beyond charity shops to fill the space
BE11:15am

(@Madruga: don't be silly and massively libellous please.)

TH11:15am

so bookies line is generally that horse racing will suffer right

Mouselet You could rezone as residential?
Blank canvas raspberry ripple ice cream is my favourite
Waterloo maybe they should open some sort of Crypto bandit machines.
11:16 am
TH11:16am

and other forms of "mature, reasonable betting"

BE11:16am

Well, it's a fairly simple argument. Fewer bookie shops mean less horse racing betting, because that's mostly counter based and closed-loop broadcast.

Mouselet Isn't it possible to bet on horse races using this newfangled Internet thing?
BE11:17am

Maybe Mr Hancock believes bookies only exist trackside. Who knows?

madrugada BE: they should never have published the article.
Mouselet (also, isn't horse racing mostly funded by exceptionally rich people who like horses?)
11:17 am
BE11:17am

(@Mouselet: possible but not wildly popular, oddly.)

BE11:18am

Worth noting here also that, at a £2 limit, GVC's kicker on the Ladbrokes deal is worthless.

BE11:18am

As in, literally worthless. It goes to zero.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Back to Davy again.

BE11:18am

Using the 6x multiple, this implies that the agreed upon position of GVC and LCL was that a £2 staking limit would cost the group £137.4m in lost EBITDA. That equates to £37,541 per shop. The EBITDA impact on LCL standalone would be 28% and 18% for the combined entity. For GVC, non-payment of any CVR would reduce its required debt (and interest charge) such that we estimate the EPS impact (vis-a- vis a £20 staking limit scenario) would be 13%. If GVC’s share price was to adjust the full 13% (and we’re not saying that it should necessarily given that there is no certainty that a £2 limit will be the eventual outcome), then the implied value of LCL shares falls to 147p (CVR 0p).

BE11:19am

William Hill has not publicly quantified what it believes the earnings impact would be on its shops of a £2 limit. However, if we were to apply the £37.5k per shop impact above, the EBITDA impact on William Hill would be c.£89m or 24%. At the EPS line, this would be 34%.For Paddy Power Betfair, using the same methodology would imply a 3-4% earnings downgrade.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(@Mouselet: I've only occasionally been to the nags. But my impression was that. if they like the horses, they're expressing it in a very odd way.)

Helen78 Interesting that if legislation isn’t in within a year of LCL/GVC closing, then GVC have to pay out on the basis of a much higher min stake. Given all the brexit legislation to get through, has to be a real risk it doesn’t get enacted in time
Mouselet ... I suppose I have made one bet ever, it was that the Brexit referendum would turn out the way it did, and I wish I hadn't won it though the £500 was nice
Forester Has HM Treasury taken to the airwaves to state how much a £2 limit would cost the UK taxpayer in terms of lost revenue & increased benefits etc?

Over 17 years, Ocado has built a platform that drives efficiency with robots, algorithms, and even some self-driving vehicles. Its latest iteration sees 50-item orders processed in 5-10 minutes coping with various complexities. Its Ocado Smart Platform now provides webshops/apps, automated fulfilment, store pick-up and last mile, with the potential for efficiency metrics such as 200+ units per hour at a 10%+ EBITDA contribution margin. This is where the value for Ocado Group will come as we head into the next decade.

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,536, up 75 (+2.17%), High: 3,578, Low: 3,470, Volume: 1.25m

Miss Piggy @Soundbuy: what face down in the snow? drunk?

Sanofi hasn't previously had an interest in haemo, so it's an interesting time to move in given Roche may or may not be about to take a lot of the market.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Here's Morgan Stanley .....

BE11:57am

[F]rom a strategic standpoint, the question is how Bioverativ’s portfolio will resist against the disruptive pressure from Roche’s Hemlibra (Bioverativ is selling short- and long-acting coagulation factors), which has so far materially impacted other players like Shire. Sanofi is developing fitusiran, in phase 3 in partnership with Alnylam, which might compete against Hemlibra from 2020 if successful (and if a clean safety profile can be demonstrated). We don’t know what the impact of US tax reform with be. Another question is how can Sanofi optimise the deal, as EU rights to the Bioverativ products belong to Sobi (not covered). Not having these rights might at some point cap the total value, in our view. Sobi has final development and commercialization rights in the Sobi territory (essentially Europe, North Africa, Russia and most Middle Eastern markets) for Eloctate (rFVIII), Alprolix (rFIX) and the candidates rFVIIIFc-VWF-XTEN/BIVV001 (rFVIII weekly dosing) and rFIXFc-XTEN/BIVV002 (rFIX – fusion protein weekly dosing). Bioverativ is expected to publish Ph I/IIa data for BIVV 001 in hemophilia A in 2H18.

TH11:57am

interesting one that, quite the premium

11:58 am
BE11:59am

And unexpected. Because haemo was not considered an area that was interesting the majors right now .....

BE11:59am

..... which puts a new spin on the idea we brought you late last year that Pfizer has shown a recent interest in Shire.

BE12:00pm

Here's UBS.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Healthcare investors with exposure to Shire, Biomarin, Spark, Roche, Chugai, Sanofi, or Alnylam will be aware that haemophilia markets face disruption. Roche's Hemlibra in haemophilia A is the most obvious near-term risk, but gene therapy is a longer-term risk in both haemophilia A and B. Today's deal announcement tells us that "Sanofi believes factor replacement therapy will remain the standard of care in hemophilia for many years." In contrast, US patients we have surveyed seem much more enthusiastic about Hemlibra and gene therapy. While we expect more treatment inertia ex-US, we wonder how durable long-term haemophilia revenues need to be to justify the deal. At what rate of erosion is the deal NPV accretive?

BE12:00pm

But having pointed out haemophilia risks, investors have been expecting Sanofi to buy something. We think that there is over-crowding and hyper-competition in oncology R&D and perhaps one or two other "hot" areas (e.g., auto-immune). In comparative terms, if Sanofi really must do deals, perhaps Bioverativ starts to look reasonable.

DF best readthrough is Sobi for Sanofi's transaction. Same company as Bioverativ, just EMEA focussed, up 11.5pc today
Tom Dalgleish @Miss if your job was blogging with self absorbed strangers then you'd take every opportunity too would you?

We take this news as a slight positive for Indivior, allowing
a cleaner launch for Sublocade, and providing an extended window for the company to get the key marketing message across: month-long blockade of cravings due to highly effective dosing. Once Indivior has done the heavy lifting with customers, payers, distributors and specialty pharmacies, Camurus/Braeburn will likely benefit from a deeper market understanding of depot-based treatment. It should also be noted, that having worked in close collaboration with the FDA, Indivior sailed through the review process, which is testament to its understanding of the condition and strength of the R&D capabilities that can now refocus on new programmes.
